suggestion:
SUMMARY: Students generally found the lecture on Vector Math to be clear and easy to follow, with some minor areas of confusion. Many students struggled with understanding when to add or subtract vectors, particularly in word problems, and how to apply trigonometric functions such as sine and cosine. Some students also had difficulty with unit vectors, including their purpose and how to use them. Additionally, a few students found the Top Hat platform to be confusing, particularly with regards to submitting answers and navigating the interface. However, overall, students appreciated the visual aids and worked examples provided in the lecture, and many felt that the material was well-explained and easy to understand.

Suggestions:

1. Emphasize the importance of understanding the context of word problems when deciding whether to add or subtract vectors. This could be achieved by providing more examples that illustrate the difference between these operations and how they apply to real-world scenarios.
2. Provide more explicit guidance on how to determine when to add or subtract vectors in word problems, such as through the use of visual aids or step-by-step examples.
3. Offer additional practice problems that focus on applying trigonometric functions, such as sine and cosine, to vector problems, to help students build their confidence and fluency in these areas.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the lecture on Angles clear and easy to follow, with some minor areas of confusion. Many students struggled with understanding when to add or subtract angles, particularly when dealing with vectors in different quadrants. Some students found it challenging to determine when to add 180 degrees to an angle, and how to identify the correct direction of a resultant vector. Additionally, students had difficulty with visualizing and drawing vectors, especially when it came to subtracting vectors. However, with the help of examples and practice, students began to understand these concepts. Overall, students appreciated the clear explanations and visual aids provided during the lecture, and were able to grasp the material with some additional practice and review.
input:
Just a quick review of when to use sin vs cos in vector math and which angles to apply, depending on which function is chosen (just because they are, technically, interchangeable)
How to stack the vectors from head to tail. When is it allowed, and when is it not?
Today's lecture was clear and for the most part easy to follow. The only part that I still am confused on is using unit vectors. However, I believe this will be covered in more detail with the next lecture.
I was confused about angle conversions in this lecture. I understand that you add based off of what quadrant the vector is in, but on an in-class example that rule didn't work, and I needed to subtract 360°. 
I think it would be more beneficial if you would go in depth of your pictures drawn and explain how they apply to a numerical problem even more.
I didn't find anything confusing or unclear during today's class. I have already taken 2 years of physics, so I know this content very well and is something I'm very comfortable with. I believe the way you taught it is very similar to how I first learned the material.
One thing I will definitely need to be looking more in to is the subtraction of vectors from the Yeti problem, when solving on my own i had a slightly different answer, so I will be trying to figure out why.
Overall, the lecture was efficient and assessed everything that was taught throughout the online lecture videos. However, going a little slower throughout the problems to let students understand and catch up through every step will allow for more information absorption. Also, during the top hat questions, it could've been more informative to go over why the incorrect answers were actually wrong.

 everything made sense, I didn't find anything confusing

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to be a challenging yet interesting topic, with many appreciating the "recipe" for drawing FBDs to make the process easier. They enjoyed applying FBDs to solve various problems, including pulley systems, the man pulling himself up, and the Atwood machine. Many students found it fascinating that pulleys can reduce the force required to lift an object, with some noting that it can be as simple as pulling with half the force of one's weight. Additionally, students appreciated the ability to redefine the system and change the coordinate system to simplify calculations, and they found the practice problems in breakout rooms to be engaging and helpful in reinforcing their understanding of FBDs.
input:
The different applications of FBD to solve problems like the example of the man supporting himself on the pulley system. 
We had one of the same problems with two people pulling a rope on each side and the tension in the rope is between both of their forces
Despite this being a difficult concept, i though the man pulling himself up with a pulley was very interesting, as it shows how pulleys can be utilized in industry 
top hat
I found the fact that forces had resisting components interesting. 
drawing free body diagrams to set up equations
I found the fact that it became 2T interesting when he pulled himself up.
The “recipe” for free body diagrams. It made drawing them a lot easier.
I found it most interesting that to hold yourself still while on a pulley system, you only need to apply the force of half your weight. 
Today, I found the conceptual problem with the man pulling up with a velocity the most interesting. If you had done the problem in your mind, then you would have gotten twice the answer. 
 The pulley system/elevator problems because I find them very fun to do.
 I found the top hat questions about normal force to be most interesting 
 Top hat question where the man on the chair pulls on the rope. I thought it was an interesting real life problem to solve.
 The part that I found most interesting about today's lecture was the conceptual questions because they were tricky.
 I found the first example with the man in the chair the most interesting.  The fact that he only has to pull with half the force of gravity was intriguing. 
 free body diagrams

 I thought learning how to draw free body diagrams was interesting. I also thought that learning about how the axes can be rotated so that more of the forces line up with them was really useful and interesting. 
 three block problem
 I enjoyed learning about pushing boxes on a frictionless surface, and how a force can be applied on it. 
 You can turn external forces into internal forces 
 Break out room problems involving free body diagrams and work
 I find tension interesting. The fact that two things can way down one rope and it's the same tension fascinated me. 
 How you can change the system you analyze in the problem depending on what you want to solve for
 Free body diagrams and how acceleration works
 Physically setting up the FBDs and solving for variables was very interesting because it's like a puzzle
 That pulley systems make it easier to lift things up
 The fact that when you are on a rope and pull yourself up you only have to pull with half the force because it is 2T
 I found the ice problem interesting. It took a lot of trial and error for me to think of the correct way, but it was interesting.
 Understanding my mistakes after he went over one of the questions on top hat
 the use of free bodies to solve the atwood machine problem with forces
 Calculating tension with the diagrams? 
 Redefining the system to make calculations faster by calling several objects the system instead of just one
 The idea of changing the coordinate system to make the problem easier
 I thought that the pulley question was very interesting. I did not know that pulleys halved the amount of weight when being pulled up.
 I found the question about the ice to be pretty interesting because I haven't thought of forces in that way before. 
 I thought it was interesting that we are taking group tests I like that and the last problem was interesting I solved it wrong but it made sense after you went through the work
 I found the part where we could treat multiple objects as the same system interesting
 The coordinates of a system are changed based on the layout of the question.
 I found the practice problems in top hat most interesting because we got to work with our fellow classmates in breakout rooms.
 The free body diagrams and how they fit together for each problem
 Good thought provoking examples made me think about things
 The free body diagrams 
 I found it interesting how you can set directions to be however you like as long as you maintain consistency. 
 The clicker questions are helpful in practicing what we have learned from the lecture videos on YouTube. 
 I found the problem with the ice block to be interesting
 Tension between two objects when there is acceleration
 The tensions and the equation chains of tensions between objects were interesting.

suggestion:
Suggestions: 

1. Consider breaking down the summary into two paragraphs to better highlight the two main aspects of the students' reflections: the challenges and the benefits of learning about Free Body Diagrams. This would make the summary easier to read and understand.
2. To make the summary more concise, focus on the most common themes and ideas expressed by the students, and avoid listing every single example or problem they mentioned. For instance, instead of mentioning "pulley systems, the man pulling himself up, and the Atwood machine" separately, you could simply say "applying FBDs to solve various problems, including pulley systems and the Atwood machine".
3. Emphasize the students' appreciation for the flexibility and problem-solving aspect of FBDs, as many students mentioned enjoying the process of redefining the system and changing the coordinate system to simplify calculations. This could be highlighted as a key takeaway from the lecture.
refined_pred:
REFINED SUMMARY:

Students found the concept of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to be a challenging yet interesting topic, with many appreciating the "recipe" for drawing FBDs to make the process easier. They enjoyed applying FBDs to solve various problems, including pulley systems and the Atwood machine, and found it fascinating that pulleys can reduce the force required to lift an object. Many students noted that it can be as simple as pulling with half the force of one's weight.

However, students also found the concept of FBDs to be difficult to grasp, requiring trial and error and a deep understanding of the underlying physics. They appreciated the flexibility and problem-solving aspect of FBDs, enjoying the process of redefining the system and changing the coordinate system to simplify calculations. The practice problems in breakout rooms were also found to be engaging and helpful in reinforcing their understanding of FBDs. Overall, students found the topic of FBDs to be engaging and challenging, with many looking forward to applying their new skills to more complex problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of free body diagrams (FBDs) to solve pulley and elevator problems to be a valuable learning experience. Many students were intrigued by the concept of pulleys reducing the force required to lift an object, with some noting that it only takes half the force of gravity to pull oneself up in a pulley system. The use of FBDs to break down complex problems into manageable parts and the ability to redefine the system to simplify calculations were also highlighted as key takeaways. Additionally, students appreciated the opportunity to practice drawing FBDs and applying them to various scenarios, including the Atwood machine problem and the ice block problem. The interactive nature of the lecture, including group work and clicker questions, was also seen as a helpful way to engage with the material and reinforce understanding.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of redefining systems to be a crucial aspect of problem-solving in mechanics, particularly when working with free body diagrams (FBDs). Many students appreciated the idea of treating multiple objects as a single system to simplify calculations and make the problem more manageable. The ability to change the coordinate system to suit the problem was also highlighted as a useful tool in solving complex problems. Additionally, students enjoyed learning how to draw FBDs and applying them to real-life scenarios, such as pulley systems and the Atwood machine. The concept of tension between objects and how it can be affected by acceleration was also found to be interesting and important. Overall, redefining systems was seen as a key strategy in breaking down complex problems into more manageable parts and making it easier to apply forces and motion concepts.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Top Hat Questions to be an engaging and interactive way to learn and practice problem-solving skills. Many appreciated the opportunity to work on real-life problems, such as pulley systems and the Atwood machine, which helped to illustrate the application of free body diagrams. Students also enjoyed the flexibility in choosing the coordinate system and the ability to treat multiple objects as a single system, which made calculations easier. Additionally, they found the practice problems in Top Hat to be helpful in reinforcing their understanding of concepts, such as tension and forces, and appreciated the ability to work with their classmates in breakout rooms. Overall, the Top Hat Questions were seen as a valuable tool for learning and reinforcing key concepts in the course.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of two blocks or forces interacting with each other to be a challenging topic, particularly when it came to understanding how to combine forces and create free body diagrams for complex systems. Many students struggled with the last example problem involving two blocks with friction, citing difficulties in understanding how to approach the problem and create the necessary equations. Some students also found it confusing to determine which type of friction to use (static or kinetic) and how to calculate the force needed to overcome friction in different scenarios. Additionally, students expressed a need for more practice and explanation on how to rearrange formulas and understand the concept of the coefficient of friction.
input:
Friction on an incline was what confused me. When more than one or two forces are applied, I feel like things are bound to get confusing. 
I found the top hat question about the two blocks hanging from the pulley the most confusing just because I understood it when I set the tensions equal to each other but not conceptually 
stacked bodys
Figuring out all the different forces that go with boxes next to each other together 
Everything was clear, just the problem with the bottom block accelerating was hard
I didn't find any of the material confusing or unclear, good lecture today
The last example with two blocks and one sliding on the other was confusing 
I was confused by the question with the two blocks where the bottom block had no friction. 
Sometimes finding the force needed to move a block, but this was typically for more complicated problems.
block on block
 Two top hat problems: the pirate and the last one with the 2 blocks stacked. I thought we went through the pirate one a little too fast, and for the last one, we ran out of time because class was ending. 
 I feel that the last question was pretty confusing during today's lecture. I believe that we should of spent more time talking through that question instead of rushing at the end of class and briefly going over it.
 The thing that was confusing about today's lecture was he conceptual question about the different between push and pull in terms of force.
 Top hat question with pulling being easier and not equal to pushing 
 I thought the last top hat question with the two masses was confusing. This is because I didn't understand how we could combine the two masses into one system when force was only being applied to the top mass.
 The two blocks on a frictionless surface was very confusing
 It was confusing to solve the problem with the friction block on the frictionless block.
 The last top hat question was the most confusing, with the two different masses and the friction between them. 
 I wasn't confused by anything this lecture. I was really good at force problems in high school and the interactive lectures really boost my confidence. 
 The last question we ran out of time
 I would like to see more example problems being done of static friction. More specifically how to use the static friction coefficient and how to develop and form the equations needed to solve each problem because I am still struggling with that concept of physics. 
 The last top hat question about the one block sitting on top of another one sitting on a frictionless surface
 The idea of doing an example not being on a wedge was a little rough. Almost everything we have done so far is on a slope.
 Everything was clear, I just feel like I need more practice on friction
 I was confused how to determine the new force using friction and an angle. 
 How the acceleration without friction can be used to find an equation of friction with acceleration
 I think that everything was covered it pretty good detail. The only thing I was slightly confused about was the last example problem, but we ran out of time at the end of the class which I think is why I was confused. 
 I was confused about what the coefficient of friction was at first but you offered a good explanation and I understand now that it's not a constant and depends on the toughness of an object.
 I did not find today's lecture confusing, but I would like to learn more about what factors determine the coefficient of friction.
 I tend to need more explanation on how formulas are rearranged and why certain forces are placed where. 
 I get confused when to use equations.  Is there a formula sheet anywhere?
 The last problem was the most confusing for me. 
 the friction over more than one block on another
 I had difficulty understanding the second to last problem that we did with the 2 boxes on top of each other, the bottom box having a coefficient of friction equal to zero with the ground.
 I am confused on the problem with the two blocks on a frictionless surface. I don't get how we combined the two free body diagrams.
 i would like more examples where you split the problem into two systems. that helps me
 Friction of one object on top of another 
 Having two blocks on top of each other with friction and determining force
 The last problem, in particular creating the equation the go to the answer 
 The thing that I found confusing in today's lecture was the last problem with the two blocks. I was unsure of how to approach it because of the free body diagrams.
 Practice problem in class about force needed to push a block onto of another block
 How to calculate the force needed to pull a block off of another block
 The last problem that dealt with the force needed to move mass 2 on top of mass 1 was tricky
 This lecture was very well taught. I really like that you showed us an exam question. It's hard to find good ones online to do practice with. It would be awesome if you could show us more exam questions. Maybe give a little more time to do them however.
 I thought that the last question was confusing 
 The problems were pretty difficult in terms of understanding the fbds and what is happening to the system and i wish there was more time given overall even for the conceptual questions
 The final exam we did in class was slightly confusing. How to find the acceleration was the only part I needed more clarification on. 
 i was confused on the final problem and how to make a diagram for both systems
 The last question regarding two objects, and one moving on top of the other. I didn't understand why F-fs = m2*a ? I had thought F-fs = 0...even though I first did equal it to m2*a
 I think the last top hat question involving the two blocks should have more explanation in the solution
 The last problem we did with the two masses was confusing because I did not know how to include the second block of ice into the problem. 
 The final example with the two blocks sliding on ice had a confusing set up
 The two blocks with the ice and friction between them
 Pushing down increasing normal force
 Why the coëfficiënt of friction is unit less and how does that work?
 do we have to always found up when solving for fsmax that way it is the force overcoming friction?

Students also had difficulty understanding how to combine FBDs for systems with multiple objects and applying the concept of friction to these systems. Additionally, there was confusion regarding the difference between kinetic and static friction, and how to determine which type of friction to use in a given problem.

Suggestions:
1. Emphasize the importance of breaking down complex problems into simpler systems to create more manageable FBDs, as suggested by students who found it helpful to split problems into two systems.
2. Provide more examples of FBDs for problems involving blocks on top of each other with frictional forces, as many students struggled with these types of problems.
3. Clarify the difference between kinetic and static friction, and provide more real-world examples to help students understand their applications, as students found this concept difficult to grasp.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students generally found the concept of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to be a challenging topic, particularly when dealing with multiple forces and objects interacting with each other. Many students struggled with creating FBDs for problems involving blocks on top of each other with frictional forces, and determining the forces acting on each block. To improve understanding, it is suggested that the instructor emphasize breaking down complex problems into simpler systems, provide more examples of FBDs for problems involving blocks on top of each other, and clarify the difference between kinetic and static friction with real-world examples. Additionally, providing more time for practice problems and explaining how to apply the concept of friction to systems with multiple objects would be beneficial.

pred: SUMMARY: Many students found the concept of centripetal force challenging to understand, particularly the direction of the acceleration vector pointing towards the center. Some students struggled with the application of centripetal force in various scenarios, such as the skydiver example and the string and mass problem. Additionally, students were confused about the relationship between centripetal force and other forces, such as normal force and friction, and how they can be considered as centripetal forces. Some students also found it difficult to derive the equations for centripetal force and struggled with understanding the units and variables involved. Overall, students would benefit from more clarification and examples to solidify their understanding of centripetal force and its application in different contexts.
input:
Centripetal force was confusing and we spent very little time on it
I need more clarification about why the acceleration vector points in toward the center. 
Circular motion, centripetal force, equations relating to circular motion
I thought the problem with the skydiver into the ocean was confusing because there were too many variables.
The last example problem we did with the string and mass. I thought we didn't spend as much time on it as I would've liked. 
I struggled with the idea of how each variable impacts the overall equation for the drag force.
The most confusing part of the lecture was determining the centripetal force. 
Circular force was a bit confusing when dealing with acceleration. 
I was a little confused by the application of acceleration at an instant when terminal velocity changes. However, your explanation cleared it up. The application of multiple g's tripped me up and I got the practice problem incorrect as I forgot a g. 
I thought the question on terminal velocity was confusing. I was confused on how to set up the equation so that all the unknown variables would end up cancelling.
 I think it was tough to conceptualize some of the drag force problems. Although it's not going to be a heavy focus for the exam, I would've liked to connect more drag force problems to conceptual ideas.
 I found the example problem where the guy hits the water very confusing because of dealing with two different  densities. 
 What was confusing about this lecture was what forces can be considered a centripetal force.  I saw that soletimes it can be the normal force or some other force.
 Circular motion/centripetal force caused by friction
 The example involving the acceleration and drag force on the jumper in the ocean.
 How circular motion works, and how the forces interact.
 Circular motion and how objects move around the circle
 The problem where the person was hitting the water confused me... I thought that because they were entering the water then mg would no longer be acting on them and the only force acting would be drag force
 The explanation of deriving the equations was confusing because it moved very quickly.
 The terminal velocity question with the difference in air and water density was challenging to see at first. 
 I was confused on the units for drag force 
 Today's lesson was not unclear or confusing. The only thing that could have been explained more in depth is centripetal force.
 I am still unclear about terminal velocity and when it is used. 
 the lesson moved really fast for such a complicated topic. deriving the equations was confusing and there weren't enough examples or applications to understand the formulas
 i found the centripetal problems a little confusing today. i think I just would like to see it more. besides that it was good. 
 A hard thing to understand is when a terminal velocity begins and ends when entering or exiting different substances.
 The first example of the terminal velocity and the acceleration before the man contacts the water.
 I felt that the first group problem was confusing but once we went over it I understood it better 
 I don't get how velocity changes when you switch between materials.
 Not too confused, just a bit worried about the exam next week.
 How the drag coefficient density of air and water can be in the same equation simultaneously 
 circular motion was barely even taught, especially the net force portion 
 On the first top hat group question finding the equation and what cancelled out 
 I think more explanation should be there for the top hat examples. I was confused at a few steps.
 Normal force on the top of a hill
 I thought the last two top hat questions were confusing 
 Trying to solve a problem with very to no numbers given and having to figure out the algebra and forces 
 The problem with sonic going around in a circle confused me because it i didn't understand why it wasn't gravity 
 Tension problems could use some more examples like like a ball on a string moving in a circular path what is theta if given length of string, mass, and r maybe.
 the difference between uniform and nonuniform circular motion
 Nothing was really confusing in today's lecture
 Drag force, in particular, knowing when to substitute
 Figuring out how to do the pendulum because the wording of the question didn't make it obvious to me
 I'm confused on how centripetal force isn't an actual force.
 the effect of density on the terminal velocity
 Some of the components of drag force are a little confusing because I'm not totally sure how they all affect the overall drag.
 I would like more details on combining circular motion with free body diagrams in three dimensions, and I would like to know how much we need to know about doing derivatives of various equations.
 I could not understand the example with the puck spinning on a table holding up a weight. How does that work?
 The drag force formula was confusing. I guess this is just because we haven't seen many of the things in it before. I'm just a little unclear as to what the units are for each one.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of histograms and graphs to be the most interesting part of the lecture, with many expressing a desire to learn more about when and how to use different types of graphs to display various data sets. They appreciated the use of a flow chart to determine which graph to use in different scenarios and enjoyed learning how to create and edit histograms in Excel. Many students also found the in-class assignment and breakout room discussions helpful in solidifying their understanding of the material, particularly in terms of identifying trends in data and calculating bin sizes. Overall, students are excited to apply their new skills in Excel and are looking forward to continuing to learn more about data analysis and visualization.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the interactive and collaborative aspects of the lecture on Talking and Exchanging Information to be engaging and valuable. The use of Excel to analyze data and create problem statements was also a highlight, as it allowed students to apply theoretical concepts to real-world scenarios. Additionally, students enjoyed the chance to share their thoughts and opinions on the CoGo Bike Share project, which helped to foster a sense of community and exchange of ideas within the class. Overall, the interactive format of the lecture enabled students to engage with the material in a hands-on and collaborative manner.

However, some students expressed confusion regarding the organization of homework and class schedule, particularly in Brightspace, and the lack of a consolidated calendar with due dates. There were also questions about the BikeShare project, including its objectives and timeline, as well as the CATME assignments and group dynamics. Some students also requested more details on how to navigate Brightspace and access assignments.

Suggestions:

1. Emphasize the importance of the Brightspace calendar and encourage students to familiarize themselves with it, as it contains crucial information about due dates and assignments. This can be done by highlighting the calendar's location and providing a brief tutorial on how to access it.
2. Provide a clear and concise explanation of the BikeShare project's objectives, timeline, and expectations in the next lecture to alleviate any confusion and give students a better understanding of what is required.
3. Offer a detailed walkthrough of the CATME assignments and group dynamics, including how to access and complete them, to ensure students understand the expectations and can plan accordingly.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: The majority of students found the lecture clear and straightforward, with many appreciating the interactive nature of the class and the helpful explanations provided. However, some students expressed confusion regarding the organization of homework and class schedule, particularly in Brightspace, and the lack of a consolidated calendar with due dates. To address this, it is recommended that the instructor emphasize the importance of the Brightspace calendar and provide a brief tutorial on how to access it. Additionally, clear explanations of the BikeShare project's objectives, timeline, and expectations will be provided in the next lecture to alleviate any confusion. A detailed walkthrough of the CATME assignments and group dynamics will also be offered to ensure students understand the expectations and can plan accordingly.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally enjoyed the breakout room sessions during the lecture, appreciating the opportunity to work with their teams and collaborate on the A12 assignment. They found it helpful to have a significant amount of time to work together, which allowed them to get on the same page and understand the material better. Many students also appreciated the application of real-world engineering practices and the use of Excel to analyze and visualize data, such as calculating instantaneous rate of change and volumetric flow rate. Some students mentioned that they enjoyed learning about different unit conversions and applying mathematical concepts to solve tangible problems. Overall, the students felt that the breakout room sessions were a valuable part of the class, allowing them to work together and learn from each other.

The design process and the opportunity to combine skills learned from previous projects were also highlighted as interesting and exciting aspects of the lecture.

suggestion:
Suggestions:

1. To make the summary more concise, consider combining similar ideas and eliminating repetitive phrases such as "students found" and "many students enjoyed." For example, "Students appreciated the in-class work on the project, which allowed them to collaborate with their groups and work on the assignment together."
2. Consider highlighting a specific aspect of the project that resonated with students, such as the fact that it's a real-world problem or the opportunity to design their own solutions. This could help to make the summary more focused and impactful.
3. To add more depth to the summary, consider incorporating specific details from the reflections, such as the mention of problem scoping, stakeholders, and the design process. This could help to give a clearer picture of what students learned and what they found interesting about the project.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students appreciated the in-class work on the project, which allowed them to collaborate with their groups and work on the assignment together. They found the process of problem scoping, particularly considering various perspectives and stakeholders, to be a valuable learning experience. The project's focus on designing a solution to a real-world problem, such as campus mobility, resonated with students as it is a relevant issue that affects them directly. The flexibility and freedom to design their own solutions and combine the skills learned throughout the semester in this final project also generated excitement and enthusiasm among students.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the problem scoping process to be the most interesting aspect of the lecture, highlighting its importance in understanding the problem from various perspectives and considering the needs of users and stakeholders. Many appreciated the hands-on experience of working in groups to generate ideas and develop a problem statement, which helped them grasp the concept and its relevance to engineering. The flexibility and freedom to design their own solutions for the final project, focusing on campus mobility, was also seen as exciting and motivating. Overall, students showed enthusiasm for the design process and the opportunity to apply the skills learned throughout the semester to a real-world problem.

Suggestions:

1. To further emphasize the students' engagement with problem scoping, consider highlighting specific quotes or phrases from their reflections that demonstrate their understanding of the concept, such as "I found the process of problem scoping interesting. This is due to the fact that you need to view the problem from a variety of perspectives" or "I found the problem scoping part to be most interesting as I understand now how useful it is to engineering." This will provide concrete evidence of their engagement and understanding.

2. To make the summary more concise, consider condensing the information and focusing on the most common themes and ideas expressed by the students. For example, instead of mentioning both "considering the needs of users and stakeholders" and "understanding the problem from various perspectives," you could combine these ideas into a single point, such as "understanding the problem from multiple perspectives, including the needs of users and stakeholders."

3. To strengthen the connection between the students' reflections and the topic of problem scoping, consider using more specific language and examples from the reflections to illustrate the concept. For example, instead of saying "the flexibility and freedom to design their own solutions was also seen as exciting and motivating," you could say "the fact that students will be designing their own solutions for campus mobility, a problem that affects them directly, was seen as exciting and motivating." This will help to create a clearer and more direct link between the students' reflections and the topic of problem scoping.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the problem scoping process to be the most engaging and interesting aspect of the lecture, highlighting its importance in understanding the problem from multiple perspectives, including the needs of users and stakeholders. Many appreciated the hands-on experience of working in groups to generate ideas and develop a problem statement, which helped them grasp the concept and its relevance to engineering. As one student noted, "I found the process of problem scoping interesting. This is due to the fact that you need to view the problem from a variety of perspectives." The flexibility and freedom to design their own solutions for the final project, focusing on campus mobility, a problem that affects them directly, was seen as exciting and motivating. Overall, students showed enthusiasm for the design process and the opportunity to apply the skills learned throughout the semester to a real-world problem.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found Assignment 17 to be confusing, particularly due to conflicting information on Brightspace and the outline document. Many students were unclear about the iteration process, the number of idea generation techniques required, and the specific parts of the assignment that needed to be completed. Some students also had difficulty understanding the concept of feedback and how it applied to the assignment. Additionally, there was confusion about the prototype requirements, with some students unsure if they needed to create a physical prototype or a diagram. The lack of clear explanation for some parts of the assignment, such as the pros and cons list and the iteration section, also caused confusion.

pred: SUMMARY: The carbon footprint calculations and activity in today's class were a highlight for many students, as it allowed them to see firsthand the impact of their individual actions on the environment. Students found it eye-opening to calculate their own carbon footprint and learn how many "earths" would be required if everyone lived like them. The use of the website to determine their carbon footprint was particularly engaging, and many appreciated the opportunity to see the contrast between their current and idealized lifestyles. Additionally, the discussion of trade-offs and the responsibilities of engineers to consider the environmental impact of their designs resonated with students, who recognized the importance of balancing economic and environmental concerns.

Remove the phrase "Overall, the students appreciated the interactive and collaborative nature of the class logistics, which they found to be engaging and informative" as it is a general statement that doesn't add much to the summary, and instead focus on the specific points mentioned in the reflections.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the in-class assignments and activities related to equations and formulas to be the most confusing aspects of the lecture. Many students struggled with understanding which variables to use and how to apply the formulas, particularly in the context of the Taum Sauk project. Some students also found the laminar approach and creating mathematical models to be unclear, and wished for more explanation and examples. Additionally, there were some difficulties with understanding the instructions for assignment 10, including creating models and using Excel regressions. Overall, students appreciated the instructor's reminders of deadlines and the opportunity to ask questions in breakout rooms, but felt that more clarification and guidance would have been helpful in understanding the equations and formulas.

pred: SUMMARY: The students found the discussion on engineering failures to be a compelling and thought-provoking topic, with many expressing interest in the real-world examples presented, particularly the Taum Sauk reservoir case study. They appreciated the opportunity to analyze the causes of these failures, including negligence, lack of proper ethics, and oversights in design and communication. The students also highlighted the importance of good communication, documentation, and considering all possible perspectives in preventing such catastrophic failures. Many noted that even small flaws or miscalculations can lead to massive consequences, emphasizing the need for diligence and accountability in engineering practices. The students enjoyed working in groups and analyzing the variables and causes of the failures, finding it a valuable learning experience that will help them in their future careers.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of trade-offs to be a fascinating topic, particularly in the context of designing and engineering solutions. Many appreciated the discussion on how engineers must consider various factors and make decisions that balance competing demands, such as environmental impact, cost, and performance. The in-class activity on calculating the carbon emissions of their personal vehicles was also a highlight, as it helped students understand the tangible effects of their daily choices on the environment. The idea of trade-offs was seen as a valuable tool for engineers to apply in their future projects, and several students appreciated the real-world relevance of this concept to their own lives and the world around them.

Consider removing the phrase "Overall, students were enthusiastic about the topic and appreciated the opportunity to explore the intersection of nature and design." as it is somewhat redundant and does not add new information to the summary. pred: SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on carbon emissions to be a highlight of the lecture, with many expressing interest in learning about the environmental impact of their daily actions and the role of engineers in addressing climate change. The hands-on activity of calculating their own car's carbon emissions, using tools such as the CO2 emissions calculator, was particularly engaging and eye-opening for many students. The concept of trade-offs and the importance of considering the environmental effects of their projects was also a key takeaway from the lecture. Overall, students appreciated the interactive nature of the class and the opportunity to explore the significance of carbon emissions in their personal and professional lives.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the lecture on projects to be straightforward and easy to follow, with most expressing that they understood the material well. However, some confusion arose regarding the specifics of assignment A16, particularly with regards to the sections due and the workload. Additionally, students struggled with understanding the differences between criteria and constraints, as well as the roles of stakeholders and clients. However, there were some areas of confusion, particularly regarding the distinction between criteria and constraints, and how to identify and incorporate stakeholders into the project. Additionally, a few students were unclear about how to empathize with users, especially those who are online students, and how to gather data for the project.

Suggestions:
1. To clarify the distinction between criteria and constraints, consider providing more explicit examples or visual aids to illustrate the differences between the two concepts, as some students still found it confusing.

3. To support online students in empathizing with users, consider providing additional guidance or resources on how to gather information about users remotely, such as through surveys or online interviews, and how to analyze and incorporate this information into the project.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally found the prototyping and testing section of the lecture confusing, particularly when it came to creating and testing prototypes without physical materials. Many students struggled with determining the level of detail required for their prototypes and how to effectively test them, especially when using CAD software. Some students also found it challenging to understand how to test their virtual prototypes, and there was a lack of clarity on the testing protocol and experiment design. Additionally, students were unsure about the feasibility of testing prototypes with limited resources and materials, especially when working remotely.
input:
Today's class was little confusing and I didn't need any extra details.
Prototyping 
The prototype section, specifically testing, is VERY confusing. My team is unsure how we are supposed to test our prototypes, especially if they are created using CAD software. Without purchasing materials, I'm unsure what could be used to create and test our solutions.
How detailed we need to be in our prototypes. 
Finding ways to develop a prototype for our idea 
I was confused about how to make a prototype for one of our designs originally. 
Nothing was confusing in today's class
I didn't get what materials i should use for prototype 
Something that could use more details in today's class was the schedule with our new reading day, because you went over it kind of quick and I didn't catch all the dates. 
We as a team found it difficult to find out not only how we would build a prototype, and how to test it. Unless we make them individually, physical prototypes aren't really feasible due to our separation. Additionally we couldn't figure out doable but also reliable ways to test our prototypes. 
 I thought the most difficult aspect of today's class was determining how to prototype our ideas to show the functionality of them.
 How we should develop a testing protocol is unclear. I don't remember going over it in the video modules and it isn't explained in the technical brief or assignment 17 instructions. I think going through an example of a testing protocol for the smart recycling bins would have been beneficial to the teams' understanding of what a testing protocol is and how to develop an effective one. 
 The confusing part about today was figuring out how my group will make the prototypes and test them in life. This was confusing for us because one of our team members is off campus, so we need to figure out how to test the prototypes and how we are making them.
 Everything made sense into today's class. But I wish there was more explanation to the ways we could create prototypes if the software option was not available to use. Other than that, everything made sense.
 I found it interesting the different types of modeling that could be used
 What was confusing was how the prototypes the groups create will be tested. My group was having a hard time understanding how this would be done virtually and with models of our design (given we don't have the ability to make real models of our prototype with the materials we wanted)
 The details for the assignment was confusing to me. The team was confused on what CAD software to use and some of the other elements of the assignment. I think after the slides are posted we will be able to review it and answer our questions.
 A confusing thing was the building of prototypes. It was confusing because of the use of materials that aren't easily accessible. 
 I am unsure of when A18 is due because bright space still has it down for next Friday. But it was said that we will work on it next Friday in class as well.
 I think prototyping in general is a bit confusing, at least to me. I dont really know how should I approach prototype making. 
 It was a little confusing how we are supposed to test our prototypes without actually having physical prototypes. My group is doing CAD models, and are having difficulty determining how we are going to effectively test our models, as they aren't really something we can just go out and test.
 How we can test our ideas was confusing because our ideas must be used on such a large sclae and we have such limited materials.
 I did not completely understand how through our prototypes had to be.
 Nothing was confusing or hard to understand. Everything was very clear 
 I haven't been exposed to a lot of the prototyping methods like CAD, so I feel like it might be pretty tough to learn something like that in the next week. 
 I thought it was confusing when we talked about the surveys because I was unsure if they counted as part of the prototype testing process. 
 I wasn't confused about anything today. We just had a few hiccups with our last grade and discussed with the TA what we got wrong.
 I thought that the discussion of the importance of prototyping was interesting. It had good information and was easy to follow.
 How we should go about testing any physical model that we create
 I would've appreciated if we went over some examples of what a strong experiment looks like versus a weak one. Additionally, how we could measure if our experiments were successful.
 I am confused on how to exactly test my virtual prototypes. 
 Knowing how to prototype virtually can be difficult and confusing at times, and having useful accessible materials is not always possible.
 One thing that was confusing about today's class was how are we supposed to test our design on a virtual platform if the platform only allows you to design not test? Or do you have to make the physical prototype and then test?
 I found it confusing how we are going to create a prototype for some of our designs
 I was a bit confused still on how detailed we needed to make our prototypes especially since we don't always have the resources
 What options we would have for making prototypes. If there were things we are not allowed to do on campus that would limit what we can do. 
 How in depth the experiments should be
 I was confused as to how to actually test a prototype. 
 Nothing today 
 nothing was confusing
 The research method and way of testing was confusing. Nothing was clarified.
 More details about the testing procedure section would be helpful 
 Thinking of prototypes while most of our ideas had to do with the road was confusing
 Nothing was confusing today. There was nothing to be confusing though because everything explained had to do with methods of prototyping.
 We only had one confusing point during the lecture, we didn't understand if it was supposed to be 3 different designs or 3 different ideas prototyped. This was solved however in our breakout room 
 Nothing was confusing today! Professor Menekse explained the prototyping process well, which helped us to discuss ways to make prototype our designs
 Everything was clear and easy to understand
 How we should make a prototype that we can also test, for example cad models would be hard to test for a18.
 Nothing
 the specifications of assignment 18 needed a bit more clarification, but otherwise all was pretty clear 
 I was confused by the way we can implement questions for the concrete details

SUMMARY: Students found the prototyping and testing section of the lecture confusing, particularly when it came to creating and testing prototypes without physical materials. Many students struggled with determining the level of detail required for their prototypes and how to effectively test them, especially when using CAD software. Some students also found it challenging to understand how to test their virtual prototypes, and there was a lack of clarity on the testing protocol and experiment design. Additionally, students were unsure about the feasibility of testing prototypes with limited resources and materials, especially when working remotely.

Suggestions:

1. Emphasize the importance of clear instructions and examples for testing protocols and experiment design in the technical brief and assignment instructions to alleviate confusion and provide a clear understanding of the expectations.
2. Provide more detailed explanations and examples of how to test virtual prototypes, including CAD models, to help students understand the feasibility of testing in this format.
3. Consider offering additional resources or support for students who are new to CAD software or prototyping methods, such as tutorials or workshops, to help them better understand and implement these concepts.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the prototyping aspect of the lecture to be the most engaging and interesting part of the class, with many expressing excitement and enthusiasm for the hands-on experience of creating prototypes. Several students highlighted the value of brainstorming and collaboration with peers to generate ideas and solutions, as well as the use of CAD software and 3D printing as tools for prototyping. The availability of various clients for virtual prototyping and the use of surveys to obtain feedback on prototypes were also seen as beneficial. Additionally, students appreciated the opportunity to learn about different materials and methods for prototyping, including the use of cardboard and duct tape, and the access to free software through ITAP. Overall, students were eager to apply their knowledge and skills to create and test prototypes, and were looking forward to the next milestone in the project.

pred: SUMMARY: The majority of students found the lecture on Assignment 17 to be clear and straightforward, with only a few areas of confusion. input:
Nothing was confusing in today's class. the only thing I had a hard time with was thinking of pros and cons for the two coffee makers because I don't drink coffee. This was the only thing that was a little confusing for me. 
Everything was very well explained: I have no complaints!
Nothing in today's class was super confusing. It was all pretty self explanatory.
I think that the example for pros and cons could have been better. I don't drink coffee, so I didn't really have much perspective for the problem.
I think the instructions on the  a17 assignement were not completely clear. I also had trouble understanding wether the costumer service introduction we had i  class needs to be included in our proyect or not
The extent of the in class assignment was the most confusing thing in today's class. Ex: how many pros and cons and geared towards what
Nothing was super confusing. At first I was worried because A17 is a lot, but once it was clarified that we didn't need to do all of them it made a bit more sense. 
I didn't think anything was confusing for today's class. I thought it all made sense and was very clear. One thing that I think could significantly improve our class is making the class slides available in Brightspace once the class begins. This would be very helpful to the teams, because often what we are working on in the assignment during team class time is related to what was in the slides and what we went over in the class. Having the slides as a reference would be extremely helpful to the teams in using their time most efficiently.

I was confused as to how to use/create the chart under functional decomposition but my team helped me out.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found problem scoping to be an engaging and interesting topic, particularly when applied to real-world projects. Many appreciated the opportunity to learn about the differences between novice and professional engineers, and how they approach problem scoping. The process of developing ways to measure constraints and criteria was also highlighted as a valuable learning experience. Additionally, students enjoyed working in groups to assign roles and start brainstorming solutions for the new project, and appreciated the clarification on the distinction between stakeholders, clients, and end-users. Overall, the hands-on approach to problem scoping and the application of this concept to a real-world problem (campus safety) resonated with students and sparked their interest in the design process.

pred: SUMMARY: Students demonstrated a solid understanding of the Red-Black BST concept, particularly its properties and operations. They grasped the importance of maintaining a balanced tree with a total number of black edges to any leaf node being the same, resulting in a theta(log n) runtime for all operations. The students were able to describe the rotation operations (left and right) and their impact on the tree structure. Additionally, they recognized the need to temporarily create violations of the Red-Black BST conditions during insertion to later resolve them, and were able to identify the three states that the tree transitions through during the insertion process.

The students were able to describe the rotation operations (left and right) and their impact on the tree structure, recognizing how these operations help maintain balance and adhere to Red-Black BST conditions. Additionally, they understood the need to temporarily create violations of the Red-Black BST conditions during insertion to later resolve them, and were able to identify the three distinct states that the tree transitions through during the insertion process.

SUMMARY:

Overall, students need further clarification on the fundamental concepts of inductors and their role in circuits.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the in-class demonstrations to be a valuable learning tool, particularly in understanding complex concepts such as resonance, phasors, and the relationships between inductors, capacitors, and resistors. The use of visual aids like the oscilloscope and projected meter readings helped students visualize and grasp the concepts more easily. Many students appreciated the interactive nature of the demonstrations, which allowed them to see the effects of different circuit components and frequencies on the circuit's behavior. The hands-on experience and visual representations also made it easier for students to solve practice problems and understand the relationships between variables, such as the resonance frequency and the amplitudes of the current and voltage.
